true_name: Asterion ("Starry One") - a name shared with Minos's stepfather
symbolism: The Minotaur has proven one of mythology's most symbolically rich figures, inspiring interpretation from antiquity to the present day:
description: Associated with Monstrosity, the labyrinth, human sacrifice.
mythology_story: The tale of the Minotaur is one of broken vows, divine vengeance, and ultimately heroic triumph. It begins not with the monster itself, but with a king's hubris and a god's wrath. When the time came for the third tribute, Theseus , the young prince of Athens and son of King Aegeus (or of Poseidon himself, by some accounts), volunteered to join the sacrificial group. He swore to his father that he would slay the monster and end Athens's shame forever. If he succeeded, he would raise white sails on his return; if he perished, the ship would bear black sails of mourning.
symbols: Bull horns, the labyrinth spiral, the double axe (labrys), Cretan palace iconography
dwelling: The Labyrinth at Knossos - an inescapable maze constructed by Daedalus
habitats: The Labyrinth at Knossos - an inescapable maze constructed by Daedalus
nature: Half-man, half-bull - with the head and tail of a bull upon a massive human body; a creature of unnatural birth, neither fully beast nor man
primarySources: Life of Theseus by Plutarch (c. 75 CE)
name: The Minotaur
domains: Monstrosity, the labyrinth, human sacrifice, divine punishment, the beast within humanity
origin: Born of Queen Pasiphae and the Cretan Bull, through Poseidon 's curse upon King Minos
abilities: Supernatural Strength: Vastly stronger than any human
Labyrinth Mastery: Perfect navigation of complex mazes
Horns: Devastating goring attacks and tossing power
Endurance: Can subsist in darkness for indefinite periods
Intimidation Aura: Mere presence strikes fear in hearts
weaknesses: Linear Thinking: Can be confused by complex strategic plans
The Thread: Can be tracked and led back out via Ariadne's thread
Mortal Vulnerability: Despite strength, can be slain by a determined hero
Isolation: Separated from potential allies by the Labyrinth
habitat: The Labyrinth of Daedalus, dark maze beneath Crete
behavior: Savage and instinctive, but capable of reason, lonely and bitter

christian.overview: The Minotaur's imprisonment in the labyrinth and eventual slaying by a hero provided rich material for Christian allegory about Christ's descent into death and victory.

biblicalParallels.description: The Minotaur fed on human tribute parallels sin's demand for death.
Christ entering death to destroy the one with power of death parallels Theseus entering the labyrinth.

patristicInterpretation.summary: The labyrinth represents sin's snares; the thread represents Christ maintaining connection to divine life.

sources.author: Origen
sources.interpretation: Theseus with the thread represents Christ descending into death while maintaining divine life.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: The Minotaur represents bestial sin in the labyrinth of the fallen heart.
medievalSymbolism.cathedrals: Cathedral floor labyrinths (like Chartres) invited walking meditation on the soul's journey.
medievalSymbolism.danteConnection: Dante places the Minotaur in Inferno XII guarding the circle of violence.

christian.typologicalReading: The Minotaur narrative prefigures the Harrowing of Hell: Christ descends, defeats the monster of death, leads captives free.
scholarlyReferences: Doob, Penelope Reed. The Idea of the Labyrinth. Cornell University Press, 1990.
